supporting.text: Not all cancer patients are unable to work; many continue employment during treatment or remission.

attacks.text: Not all cancer patients are unable to work; many continue employment during treatment or remission.
Some cancer treatments, such as chemotherapy, can severely impair a patient's ability to work due to side effects like fatigue and nausea.
Many workplaces offer accommodations for cancer patients, allowing them to continue working despite treatment side effects.
Certain aggressive cancers, like late-stage pancreatic cancer, often leave patients too debilitated to maintain employment.
Early detection and improved treatments have increased the number of cancer patients who can maintain employment during and after treatment.

supporting.text: Disability benefits often require meeting specific severity or functional impairment criteria, which not all cancer patients satisfy.

attacks.text: Disability benefits often require meeting specific severity or functional impairment criteria, which not all cancer patients satisfy.
Many cancer patients experience severe symptoms or treatment side effects that meet disability criteria.
Even with severe symptoms, bureaucratic hurdles and inconsistent evaluation standards can prevent some patients from qualifying.
Certain cancers (e.g., metastatic or terminal cases) automatically qualify for expedited disability approval in many jurisdictions.
Automatic qualification policies vary widely by region and may exclude patients with less aggressive cancers.

supporting.text: Some cancer treatments allow patients to maintain normal daily activities without qualifying for disability.

attacks.text: Some cancer treatments allow patients to maintain normal daily activities without qualifying for disability.
Many cancer treatments, such as chemotherapy and radiation, cause severe side effects that impair daily functioning and qualify patients for disability.
Even with milder treatments, cancer patients often experience fatigue, pain, or cognitive issues that may still qualify them for disability under certain criteria.
Disability qualification depends on legal and medical definitions, which vary by jurisdiction and may exclude some cancer patients.
Most jurisdictions recognize cancer as a presumptive disability due to its unpredictable progression and treatment impacts.

supporting.text: Disability eligibility varies by jurisdiction, and not all regions automatically grant it for cancer diagnoses.

attacks.text: Disability eligibility varies by jurisdiction, and not all regions automatically grant it for cancer diagnoses.
Many jurisdictions have streamlined processes for cancer patients to receive disability benefits due to the severity of the condition.
Even with streamlined processes, some cancer patients may not meet the specific medical or bureaucratic criteria required for disability approval.
Certain types of cancer, especially early-stage or highly treatable forms, may not qualify for disability benefits in most jurisdictions.

supporting.text: Early-stage cancer patients often have minimal symptoms and do not meet disability thresholds.

attacks.text: Early-stage cancer patients often have minimal symptoms and do not meet disability thresholds.
Even early-stage cancer can cause significant fatigue, pain, or cognitive impairment, which may qualify as disabilities under certain legal frameworks.
Disability thresholds vary by jurisdiction, and many early-stage cancer patients may still qualify for temporary or partial disability benefits.
Some early-stage cancers require aggressive treatments (e.g., surgery, chemotherapy) that temporarily disable patients regardless of initial symptom severity.

supporting.text: Private or employer-based insurance may not classify cancer as a disability unless it causes significant functional limitations.

attacks.text: Private or employer-based insurance may not classify cancer as a disability unless it causes significant functional limitations.
Many legal frameworks, such as the ADA in the U.S., recognize cancer as a disability regardless of functional limitations.
The ADA's broad definition of disability is not universally adopted by private insurers or employers outside the U.S.
Even under the ADA, proving disability status for cancer may require documentation of impairment or treatment side effects.
Early-stage cancers with high cure rates often don't qualify for disability benefits under any system.
